content:
I am trying to make Gemini (Flash 2.0 Exp) teach me Lean4, but its own knowledge of Mathlib is outdated. It wanted to prove this simple law, but it couldn't figure out the imports needed. I've almost managed to find the imports, but they need to be narrowed still. Can someone help me with figuring out the right way of proving this, and importing the right modules?

import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Calculus --  <-- Crucial import identified!

-- open EuclideanSpace  -- Comment out this line

theorem vec_add_comm (v w : EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2)) : v + w = w + v := by -- Use full path for EuclideanSpace
  apply add_comm  -- Try `apply add_comm` again
#min_imports at the end of the file will tell youimport Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2.
The output of #min_imports does not take into account tactics/notation, so it may be not completely reliable. However, this is usually not an issue.

@Damiano Testa Oh, thank you very much! And would you have any idea if EuclideanSpace is the right way of working with Linear Algebraic entities like matrices? I am trying to learn Linear Algebra for my college. Thanks! :smile:
#mil has a chapter on linear algebra: maybe you can start looking there.

Keep in mind that learning Lean and maths at the same time is quite challenging: they both have a very steep learning curve and it can get tricky to figure your way around stuff if neither the maths nor the formalisation is clear.
However, this Zulip chat is very friendly and you are always welcome to ask questions here.
Zillion Demor has marked this topic as resolved.
